title-group.article-title: A Structural Analysis of Pension Disclosures under SFAS 87 and Their Relation to Share Prices

abstract.p: When pricing common shares, investors do not assign the same earnings multiple to all components of pension cost. And these multiples differ from the multiple assigned to earnings before pension expense. In particular, both return on plan assets and the interest cost components tend to be assigned higher multiples than earnings before pension expense. Moreover, the market appears to assign a multiple of zero to the amortization of the transition asset. Earnings analysis obviously constitutes more than just the "bottom line"; careful analysis of earnings components and of the relative importance assigned to those components is also involved. The pension balance sheet and income statement data are so correlated that, once pension balance sheet data are known, no additional information is provided by the income statement data. An analysis of the structural relations between the various pension items permits estimation of the unreported amount of the amortization of the transition asset and helps to explain the redundancy between the pension expense data and the pension balance sheet data.
